Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: Most callers are receptive, and occasional simple questions arise that the script already covers.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the screen still lit up from my girlfriend’s last message: “We need to talk about the bills tonight.” My stomach twisted. We’d argued three times this week about money—her frustration simmering, my explanations sounding more like excuses each time. I knew she expected me to step up, to help us find a solution, to be the boyfriend who could resolve things instead of letting them fester.

But right now, I was at my desk, headset on, dialing the next number on my telemarketer list. The script was easy, the customers mostly polite, their questions predictable. “Is there a contract?” “What’s the monthly fee?” I had answers ready, my voice smooth and reassuring. My manager expected me to keep my numbers up, to handle every objection with a smile.

Yet, as I listened to a customer ask about cancellation policies, my mind drifted back to my girlfriend’s words. I felt pulled in two directions—one voice urging me to focus on the call, the other whispering that I couldn’t keep putting off the conversation at home. My heart pounded as I tried to juggle both, knowing I couldn’t give either role what it truly needed from me.
